content: We have the data-carrying class docs#CategoryTheory.RegularEpi and an abbrev docs#CategoryTheory.IsRegularEpi which just means Nonempty RegularEpi, effectively making it into a prop-valued version of the former class. In particular, we can have instances of both forms [RegularEpi f] and [IsRegularEpi f]. This is bad, and I think only the latter should be a class (this is what we do for docs#CategoryTheory.EffectiveEpi, which works quite well). I propose to changeRegularEpi to a non-class structure and IsRegularEpi to a one-field class saying that RegularEpi is nonempty. I suspect that all current instance arguments of the form [RegularEpi f] can easily be changed to [IsRegularEpi f] after this change. Are there any objections to this?
I guess, you can start by changing all [RegularEpi f] to [IsRegularEpi f] to see if the data part is ever used in the statement.
While we are it, I think it would also be nice to rename the current RegularEpi to RegularEpiStruct and the current IsRegularEpi to RegularEpi. This follows the naming scheme of EffectiveEpi.

I'm not sure whether I like the Is- or the -Struct version better. Keeping the same names has the advantage of not needing to deprecate anything. If we do the name change that could be a separate PR anyway
